Prev tweets on consecutive +2% $ SPX days are mainly trivia;tho, current streak does seem atypical of such streaks (if there's such a thing).
This back-to-back +2% $ SPX up day run began with the $ VIX at 23.57; prior streaks began with an median $ VIX of about 50.
Of the 29 consecutive +2% days in the S&P 500 since 1950, this was the only one that began w/ the $ VIX below 26 (23.57). $ SPY
Of the 29 consecutive +2% days in the S&P 500 since 1950, this one showed the 2nd biggest % $ VIX drop @-27% (10/21/1987). $ SPY
Of the 29 consecutive +2% days in the S&P 500 since 1950, this one showed the 2nd weakest gain at +4.49% (9/19/1975). $ SPY
@ AndrewThrasher Proposal: an exception can be made if also providing a comparison to 2009 or 1982.
Of the 29 consecutive +2% days in the S&P 500 since 1950 this was just the 2nd that began above the 200-Day moving average (10/7/1982). $ SPY
Of the 29 consecutive +2% days in the S&P 500 since 1950, this was just the 2nd that began within 10% of its 2-year high (3/16/2000). $ SPY
Btw, according to our criteria we've officially recorded another V-Bottom -- the 10th in 21 months after 38 total in the previous 63 years.

Reason #5) The Dow closed at a 16-Day High & High Yield Bonds closed at a 16-Day Low (happened 28 times since 1996 w/ Dow at a 52-Wk High).
Reason #4) Since 1991, the NDX has closed at a 52-Week High on 603 days. Yesterday ranked 600th in Russell 2000 performance.
Reason #3) Since 1965, the Dow has closed at a 52-Week High on 994 days. Yesterday ranked 992nd in NYSE Advances-Declines.
Reason #2) Since 1988, the Nasdaq has closed at a 52-Week High on 717 days. Yesterday ranked 716th in Nasdaq Advances-Declines.
Reason #1) Since 1988, the S&P 500 has closed up on 3602 days. Yesterday ranked 3590th in NYSE+Nasdaq Advances-Declines.
